title: Wednesday, 8th March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Yo

PM11:01am

And welcome to Budget Day on Alphaville

PM11:02am

Which means, by tradition, that we do bugger all -- while the rest of the newsroom here goes into orbit

11:02 am
PM11:02am

The tradition thing is cos in my last job Budget Day was the worst day of the year

PM11:02am

Too much work to do and egos to smooth

PM11:02am

Modern news editors have it easy on budget day

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Cos the chancellor speaks early

PM11:03am

It used to be that he (always a he) didnt stand up till 4.30

PM11:03am

Spoke for an hour

11:03 am
PM11:03am

And then you had circa 30k words of copy to commission and process by 7.30

PM11:03am

Madness

PM11:04am

Anyway, Alphaville slacks off on budget day

11:03 am
PM11:04am

Even slacker

PM11:04am

Bryce!

PM11:04am

What do we kick around?

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Rude not to dwell a moment or two on Numis and Schroders....

undefined
BE11:05am

Oh, go on .....

11:05 am
PM11:05am

So story here: https://www.ft.com...-aa5b-6bb07f5c8e12

BE11:05am

Ah.

PM11:05am

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our T&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights.
https://www.ft.com...-aa5b-6bb07f5c8e12

Numis, the brokerage that last week criticised Schroders, the UK fund house, for using “disingenuous” investment performance figures, has retracted the comment and issued an apology in a further twist to an unusual public dispute.

The broker last week objected to a Schroders press release that prominently stated 74 per cent of the company’s assets had outperformed their benchmark over three years, rising to 85 per cent over five years.

In a footnote on page five of the press release, Schroders clarified the performance figures only applied to a subset of its funds as it did not have sufficient information to measure performance across all of its assets.

The FTSE 100 fund company did not state that performance was measured before fees were deducted.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Very good tale from Cat Rutter Pooley and Madison Marriage

BE11:05am

Hm.

PM11:05am

Some of our colleagues have terrific bylines

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Wish I had a byline like that

BE11:06am

Disingenuous is an interesting word, isn't it?

BE11:06am

Comes from the same root as genus, as in race, kind or class.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Suppose Bryce Elder is rather good

PM11:06am

Paul Murphy is rubbish

BE11:06am

Ingenuous in a literal sense means "in character" ... acting in a way that befits your freeborn nature.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Disingenuous is the opposite.

PM11:06am

hmm

BE11:07am

People think it's just a polite euphemism for lying.it's not.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

It's more pointed that that. It's the idea that you've let down your heritage.

BE11:07am

Now, the original Numis note has been expunged from the database .....

PM11:07am

Omg smile

11:07 am
BE11:07am

So to get some context here, I've dug out the Schroders conference call ....

PM11:08am

(very good DutchBrat)

PM11:08am

Excellent Bryce

11:08 am
BE11:08am

In which David McCann (Numis) and Peter Harrison (Schroders) outline their arguments in full.

PM11:08am

Ah, he can be our pic of the day

PM11:08am

11:08 am
PM11:09am

That's David

PM11:09am

PM11:09am

Taht's Peter

11:09 am
PM11:09am

But go on

BE11:09am

.... It's quite an interesting conversation. You can judge yourself whether there's any disingenuousness underlying this.

BE11:09am

Here's David ....

11:09 am
BE11:09am

I just wanted to follow up on the 85% outperforming, the point that was made a couple of times. Firstly, is that net of the fees that clients are actually paying in the actual share classes they're in or is that based on representative share classes? And secondly, is that compared to Benchmark or is compared to peer group averages? Obviously, the former being harder to beat generally.

BE11:10am

And Peter ....

BE11:10am

It depends on what it's being -- what its objective is. So if it's against a peer group, it's a peer group. If it's against an index, it's an index. It's gross for those mandates where we can make comparisons with Benchmark's. But hence the reason we do -- and it's obviously very complicated. You've got a mutual fund with 40 share classes. You could never give a simple number. Hence the reason we do a lot of work on pounds of alpha. And I think it's the -- there's a huge complexity with that, but in our submission to the FCA it was all about, are you growing the real wealth of the people who are investing in those funds after all the fees that you're charging? And it's the pounds of alpha, i.e. money-weighted returns, not time-weighted returns, which I think is the more important number, which is a positive.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

David:

BE11:10am

And it is net of charges that figure on a ...?

BE11:10am

Peter:

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Well, in the intermediary -- where you've got peer-group-related funds, those are all including the charges. Where you've got institutional mandates against Benchmark's, those are ex charges, those are gross.

BE11:10am

David:

BE11:10am

What would you estimate it might be if you were to net off the charges?

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Peter:

BE11:11am

I think we would -- it's a hugely -- the reason we don't do it is it's hugely complicated because you've got so many different share classes, et cetera to do. Because it -- we -- you bill outside of the mandate for an institutional mandate. So the billing -- the fee number is often a different number, so it's actually quite a hard -- it sounds simple, but it's actually quite a hard number to get to.

BE11:11am

David:

11:11 am
BE11:11am

But even if you were to take, say, a representative charge, take off, say, your 30 basis points institutional average margin, would that ...?

BE11:11am

Peter:

BE11:11am

Yes. That number would still be a high number.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

David:

BE11:12am

It would still -- and it would still be above 50%?

BE11:12am

Peter:

11:12 am
BE11:12am

I think it would be. I haven't proved it, but I -- because our pounds of alpha is a very positive number, then I'm confident that will be a positive number. Whether -- what the exact percentage is, I don't know.

PM11:12am

This is just terrific

BE11:12am

(Have we done dramatic dialogue on AV before? We should do it more. Broaden the medium.)

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Sell Schroders

BE11:13am

PM11:13am

This hits so many buttons

11:13 am

BE11:13am

PM11:13am

11:13 am
PM11:14am

Get a spine guys

PM11:14am

We don't even have to start the passive/active debate

PM11:14am

This is just appalling of Schroders

11:14 am
PM11:15am

In a footnote on page five of the press release, Schroders clarified the performance figures only applied to a subset of its funds as it did not have sufficient information to measure performance across all of its assets.

PM11:15am

That's not just disingenuous

PM11:15am

11:15 am

The apology does seem curiously weak. I'll not speculate on how much of Numis's daily volume comes from Schroders, and whether best execution rules would somehow allow that volume to move elsewhere. Because Chinese walls, of course.

PM11:15am

And an admission to being incompetent -- all in one

BE11:16am

Thumbs up

BE11:23am

The business conducted 70,700 funerals vs 73,500 (-4%), despite contribution from acquisitions and increase in pre-arranged. Clearly the drop in market share and underperformance of the market raises questions. Some of the loss of share may be due to imprecise data and some due to regional variances. However, there does appear to be more competition appearing, which typically offers a lower cost funeral than Dignity. The company is to introduce a lower priced online service in order to provide a simpler, lower priced offer.

BE11:23am

In terms of the numbers just past, they're fine. Death has exceeded forecasts.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Adjusted PBT rose 4% to £75.2m vs our forecast of £72.5m,
with the number of deaths ahead of the company's expectations
due to a strong end to the year. The company is not changing its
expectations for the current year, anticipating deaths to be lower
reflecting the outperformance in 2016.

BE11:24am

But ..........

BE11:24am

Focus is likely to be on the market share decline to 11.8% vs 12.3%, despite the benefit of acquisitions and pre-arranged. The company describes increased competition from new openings,
some of which will be offering lower cost funerals. This is unlikely to result in a sharp shift in the business, but it will impede progress. The company has adjusted its EPS growth expectations to 8% CAGR from 10% (including benefits of capital returns and acqn), due to the increased scale of business and greater competition – this accords with our current forecasts. Dignity continues to be a high quality business with a strong franchise and consistent growth prospects. However, this is
reflected in the 21.6x PE and 15.1x EV/EBITDA.

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 731.00, up 46.5 (+6.79%), High: 735.50, Low: 697.00, Volume: 2.21m

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Q4 revenue ex Ligado Networks of $328m was +8% ahead of cons at $304m, and EBITDA ex LN of $191m was +21% ahead of cons at $158m. At least part of the beat is attributable to a short term, one-off, bandwidth contract in US Government.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Changes to guidance (see below), the beat in Government, and the continued +5% growth in the dividend (no change in policy).
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Yes: revenue guidance for 2018 has been downgraded to $1,300-$1,500m from $1,450-$1,600m (cons $1,372m), and Inmarsat has issued 2017 revenue guidance of $1,200 - 1,300m (cons $1,255m).
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: The Q4 beat and no change to the dividend policy are likely to support the shares, while the wide range of outcomes for 2017 and 2018 guidance may raise some concerns.

BE11:41am

Today’s Q4 results are materially ahead. Whilst a sizeable proportion of the
beat is attributable to a one-off government contract contribution, underlying
revenues and EBITDA are nevertheless 2% and 11% ahead. Moreover with
IFC and the US Navy CSSC set to offer tailwinds, the 2017 revenue guidance
(in-line with consensus) seems a little prudent. Expect Q&A on the conference
call to focus on (i) the swing factors that will determine where revenues come
out against a wider than usual range, and (ii) the shape of 2017E EBITDA as
IFC costs scale. Finally Inmarsat has confirmed the long-awaited IAG contract
win, lifting the total number of mandated aircraft by ~350 to a healthy 950.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 203.45, up 1.05 (+0.52%), High: 204.30, Low: 202.15, Volume: 16.99m
BE11:46am

Vodafone offers a growing top-line about to accelerate coupled with costcutting, driving a 4-year EBITDA CAGR of 4%. Following a material derating vs.
the sector, its 9.7% CY18E FCF yield is a compelling entry point. We highlight 1)
top-line growth today despite Indian competition and roaming headwinds that
have pressured near-term growth and driven the derating; 2) self-help driving
margins +c.1ppt p.a.; 3) a covered 6.5% FY18E dividend yield; and 4) low
exposure to key investor sector concerns: B2B pressure and regulatory
uncertainty. However, our investor meetings suggest sentiment on VOD is at
long-term lows. We reiterate our Buy rating and add it to the Conviction List.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Going to jump to the M&A section, because obviously.

BE11:48am

Recent investor meetings suggest concerns that VOD could overpay for European
cable assets. We see material cost synergies available such that a deal could be value
accretive in most scenarios.
As previously published in our recent analysis, we outline our analysis for a potential
combination between Vodafone and cable players in the UK, DE and CEE below (see Selfhelp raises confidence in growth outlook published January 10, 2017).
Assessing the capital structure considerations for any combination and indeed any merged
entities in a respective country is difficult as there are numerous possibilities (based on
leverage, tax etc.). Therefore, we seek to assess what the current value of potential
synergies could be for Vodafone based on the combination of Vodafone and cable assets in
the UK, DE and CEE where there is a relevant overlap. We consider cost synergies based
on precedent transactions, notably Vodafone-KDG, Vodafone-ONO, Telenet-Base and ZonSonaecom, which targeted annual savings of 4%-8% of combined opex/capex.

BE11:49am

As before, our 12-month price targets incorporates a c.£0.10/share of potential
consolidation benefits based on our synergy-capture analysis of Vodafone merging its
businesses in UK/DE and CEE with cable players. This assumes Vodafone takes a 50%
share of synergies at the midpoint of the combined opex/capex assumptions shown above
and incorporates 30% of this potential value in our 12-month price target (these
assumptions are unchanged from before). We note uncertainty around capital structures,
and potential regulatory risk around combining fixed and mobile assets.

Worldpay Group PLC (WPG:LSE): Last: 279.78, up 7.28 (+2.67%), High: 280.20, Low: 272.40, Volume: 3.34m
PM11:51am

I had promised to usual place the stuff we shared yesterday

11:50 am
PM11:51am

PM11:51am

And will do so after this session

PM11:51am

But I think there's some fresh Credit Suisse on this thing

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Reiterate Outperform: There are some pluses and minuses in the FY16 results, but ultimately we are surprised by the
lackluster share price reaction. Specifically, in focusing on the noise of FY16, we think investors have overlooked incrementally positive comments on the medium term. Notably, the comments on FY17 were more robust than feared and while management has previously commented on the scope for margin expansion, this is the first time we have heard explicit expectations that FY18 margins (and beyond) could expand by 1% per annum. We continue to believe investors overlook the medium term growth prospects and strategic value at Worldpay and we reiterate our Outperform.

PM11:52am

We take a positive approach: Investor reaction seemed to focus on 2 aspects of the results, 1) the slight slippage in technology roll-out and marginally higher FY18 costs and 2) the sequential slowdown in growth in eCommerce. We understand frustration over the technology platform, but rather than worry about marginally higher costs, we take comfort from confirmation that the new platform works and is already being used by thousands of customers. We think this starts to de-risk the roll-out. Meanwhile, the slowdown in growth in eCommerce was due to previously disclosed gateway issues but management stressed that volumes had returned to normal. Meanwhile, the fact that Worldpay remains no1 with customers like Etsy is a positive reflection of Worldpay's position in the market.

PM11:52am

Forecasts: Looking at forecasts, there are well known tough comps in 1H17, but we are impressed that management believes it can deliver 9-11% underlying growth throughout FY17 (although this will benefit from FX tailwinds in eCom). Updating numbers for FX leads us to nudge up FY17-18 EBITDA by 0-1%, while slightly lower tax leads to 3-5% upgrades to normalised EPS. PSD2 represents a potential regulatory risk to the merchant acquiring segment, this should be monitored in detail before implementation in 2018.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Check the usual place later

BE11:52am

Citi also worth reading on Worldpay.

BE11:53am

Lack of Reason
Based on discussions with investors over the last several weeks, we think many were looking for a reason to go long Worldpay given the stock’s underperformance. We don’t think the company’s 2016 results gave them that reason, and we believe the stock will struggle to rally without evidence that WPUS --- Worldpay’s US business --- is improving.
WPUS in Focus…
WPUS was the focal point of the earnings release and analyst presentation given that it turned in what we’d call an uninspiring performance, with only 2% y/y revenue growth. WPUS has arguably been the company’s “weak link” since Worldpay’s 2015 IPO, with an ongoing effort to improve performance accompanied by some road bumps.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

...but Unlikely to be Great in 2017
With regards to WPUS, we think there were two important takeaways. First, management said that WPUS won’t get to “sustainable growth in 2017” and that “2018-2020 is the real focus.” While this doesn’t preclude the possibility that 2017 will bring sufficient evidence to persuade investors that WPUS has turned the corner operationally, it does make it seem less likely. Second, management appears very committed to retaining WPUS --- “we are there for the long haul” --- so the possibility of a sale acting as a bullish catalyst for the stock anytime soon seems remote.
More PSD2
Worldpay was the second company this earnings season to proactively address PSD2 with a slide in its presentation. We expect PSD2 to be an increasingly prominent topic of conversation in the months ahead.
Model Update
We have updated our model and our estimates don’t change materially. We suspect consensus estimates won’t change much either. We also introduce our 2019 EPS estimate of 17.87p. We roll forward our valuation model to be based off of 2019 estimates, raising our target price from £2.84 to £3.04.

BE11:53am

So there we are.

Deutsche Bank (DBKGn.DE) — Significant Execution Risk; Retain Sell Rating
Ambitious Cost Saves Limited Detail on Revenue Attrition Has The Bank Raised Enough? Sell The Shares — We increase our earnings (pre-dilution) to reflect the retention of Postbank and some of the new target cost saves. However, after adjusting for the rights issue dilution, we calculate the stock is trading on a pro-forma 2018 TERP EPS of 9.3x and TERP TBVPS of 0.6x for a c6% RoTE, rising to c8% in 2020. We see significant execution risk and reiterate our Sell (3H) rating, target price €16.
Sell/High Risk | Target price €16.00

BE11:27am

Smooth operational execution continues: Management expanded their portfolio
through the acquisition of 16 funeral locations and five crematoria in the year; £56m
investment (net of cash acquired) funded from existing cash resources, and since the
last trading update, DTY has obtained planning permission for a third new
crematorium. Additionally, DTY has acquired three funeral locations and one small
crematorium since the balance sheet date. Pre-arranged had another good year with
plans increasing by 8% to 404K helped by trust and insurance based sales.
 Valuation and recommendation: The shares have outperformed by c.8% (-3 months)
and now trade broadly in line with our 2750p target price; a Dec’17 Dec’18 PE of
22.5x 20.5x (slightly above the long-term historical median/average). Robust and
visible demand, steady 8% earnings CAGR, flawless execution and a sensibly managed
balance sheet and acquisition programme make DTY a quality core holding for
investors whose rating should be maintained at the current levels as earnings
progress, generating predictable absolute returns.
